commit_message:
Do not duplicate message consumers

Oslo.messaging creates node topic (with node name as suffix)
and fanout topic automatically. There's no need to do this
in Neutron code.

Closes bug 1413156

Change-Id: Ic790cab648b213b55679038967fef12eb5cec606
(cherry picked from commit 6da3d014bfa95c979db1d6ce18ba10d629b80481)

commit_message:
Fix image metadata returned for volumes

When creating a volume from a glance image, cinder stores the original
image metadata in volume_glance_metadata. This is a key/value store,
and all the values are strings.

When Nova boots an instance from a volume, it passes the image
metadata returned by cinder, which is all strings. If a driver
expects these values to be ints, as they are when booting from an
image, it will get a type error.

This change also pulls size from the volume directly rather than
taking the value from the stored image metadata. This is because the
volume will have been created in 1Gb increments, and is unlikely to be
the same size as the original image. It may also have been
subsequently extended.

Cherry picked from https://review.openstack.org/#/c/124010/

Closes-Bug: #1367540

Conflicts:
	nova/compute/api.py
	nova/tests/compute/test_compute.py

Change-Id: I7928f6be1ca99f1502941b9df2b443f2ca63a37b

commit_message:
Update service.py to support graceful Service shutdown

This change backports the latest version of service.py from oslo-incubator.
The latest version supports graceful shutdown for the Service class, which is
needed to enable graceful shutdown for the Ironic Conductor.

Change-Id: Ide6b549aa64333b7781f3525c6d2ccb8762402bf
Partial-Bug: #1382698
(cherry picked from commit dd542195750a19b16a6b1a7cf89d45c70ef2ae61)

subject: Exclude empty tiers from max_replicas
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-16 04:24:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/64c5740b99b7ab91ba69f6496da89f15789b832f', 'message': "Exclude empty tiers from max_replicas

If you have ring with less failure domains at a tier than replicas the
max_replicas count for the failure domains at that tier already expect to have
a max_replicas > 1.  For example, on a two node deployment, each of the two
failure domains at the server tier is expected to have no more than *two*
replicas of any part (surely it would be a problem if either server had all
three replicas, but we expect some doubling).  If you have a third server, the
max_replicas drops from 2 to 1 at each of those failure domains as they should
only have at most a single copy of any partition or there's a dispersion
problem.

But if that third server is being decommissioned and all of it's device's
weight are set to zero then you don't really have three failure domains at
that tier and the max_replicas should be go back to 2 not 1.  Also any parts
stuck in the tier with weight zero probably shouldn't be there - so you've got
some kind of problem if there's *any* replicas in a zero weight tier
*regardless* of the number of failure domains.

I came to this when I was playing around with a topology migration that was
moving a zone.  You start with two zones and everything is dispersed, you add
a third zone and everything gets even *more* dispersed, then you remove one of
the first zones that you're migrating off of and suddenly there's a problem
because the two zones you're migrating to have > 1 replica of some parts.  Two
zones was fine before, so what's the problem?

Turns out the problem was a failure domain with zero weight still drains off a
replica from the max_replicas of the other failure domains at that tier.

Eventually I think it's pretty sane that the operator would remove the zero
weight devices from the ring, and then max_replicas will go back to saying
each of the two failure domains at this tier may have at most 2 replicas.  But
because it's not always obvious when replication is finished just by looking
at partition placement theres a disconnect and window where things seem to be
saying it's worse than it really is.

When a tier has zero weight max_replicas acts like the max_replicas at that
tier should be 0.  We do expect that occasionally a tier with zero weight will
have replicas assigned to it because min_part_hours - but I think thats also
bad and worth flagging as a dispersion problem - although maybe it's
conflating of seperate issues.

Someone else might have a counter example where this would not be the desired
behavior, and I'm not 100% sure it's going to always say the right thing in
every use case - but as it's done currently I've got at least one concrete
example where I think the current behavior doesn't make sense.

Change-Id: I68d47ff0667788442342d55b8041aed80d0b2161

commit_message:
Exclude empty tiers from max_replicas

If you have ring with less failure domains at a tier than replicas the
max_replicas count for the failure domains at that tier already expect to have
a max_replicas > 1.  For example, on a two node deployment, each of the two
failure domains at the server tier is expected to have no more than *two*
replicas of any part (surely it would be a problem if either server had all
three replicas, but we expect some doubling).  If you have a third server, the
max_replicas drops from 2 to 1 at each of those failure domains as they should
only have at most a single copy of any partition or there's a dispersion
problem.

But if that third server is being decommissioned and all of it's device's
weight are set to zero then you don't really have three failure domains at
that tier and the max_replicas should be go back to 2 not 1.  Also any parts
stuck in the tier with weight zero probably shouldn't be there - so you've got
some kind of problem if there's *any* replicas in a zero weight tier
*regardless* of the number of failure domains.

I came to this when I was playing around with a topology migration that was
moving a zone.  You start with two zones and everything is dispersed, you add
a third zone and everything gets even *more* dispersed, then you remove one of
the first zones that you're migrating off of and suddenly there's a problem
because the two zones you're migrating to have > 1 replica of some parts.  Two
zones was fine before, so what's the problem?

Turns out the problem was a failure domain with zero weight still drains off a
replica from the max_replicas of the other failure domains at that tier.

Eventually I think it's pretty sane that the operator would remove the zero
weight devices from the ring, and then max_replicas will go back to saying
each of the two failure domains at this tier may have at most 2 replicas.  But
because it's not always obvious when replication is finished just by looking
at partition placement theres a disconnect and window where things seem to be
saying it's worse than it really is.

When a tier has zero weight max_replicas acts like the max_replicas at that
tier should be 0.  We do expect that occasionally a tier with zero weight will
have replicas assigned to it because min_part_hours - but I think thats also
bad and worth flagging as a dispersion problem - although maybe it's
conflating of seperate issues.

Someone else might have a counter example where this would not be the desired
behavior, and I'm not 100% sure it's going to always say the right thing in
every use case - but as it's done currently I've got at least one concrete
example where I think the current behavior doesn't make sense.

Change-Id: I68d47ff0667788442342d55b8041aed80d0b2161
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/43/147743/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # test add another dev with no id # test a legit builder # test old style builder # test old devs but no meta # test an empty builder # test a corrupted builder # test some error # test non existent builder file # test non accessible builder file # test an error other then ENOENT and ENOPERM def test_dispersion_with_zero_weight_devices(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3.0, 0) # add two devices to a single server in a single zone rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) # and a zero weight device rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 0, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.rebalance() self.assertEqual(rb.dispersion, 0.0) self.assertEqual(rb._dispersion_graph, { (0,): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000'): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 0): [0, 128, 128, 0], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 1): [0, 128, 128, 0], }) def test_dispersion_with_zero_weight_devices_with_parts(self): rb = ring.RingBuilder(8, 3.0, 1) # add three devices to a single server in a single zone rb.add_dev({'id': 0, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sda'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 1, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdb'}) rb.add_dev({'id': 2, 'region': 0, 'zone': 0, 'weight': 1, 'ip': '127.0.0.1', 'port': 10000, 'device': 'sdc'}) rb.rebalance(seed=1) self.assertEqual(rb.dispersion, 0.0) self.assertEqual(rb._dispersion_graph, { (0,): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000'): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 0): [0, 256, 0, 0], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 1): [0, 256, 0, 0], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 2): [0, 256, 0, 0], }) # now mark a device 2 for decom rb.set_dev_weight(2, 0.0) # we'll rebalance but can't move any parts rb.rebalance(seed=1) # zero weight tier has one copy of *every* part self.assertEqual(rb.dispersion, 100.0) self.assertEqual(rb._dispersion_graph, { (0,): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000'): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 0): [0, 256, 0, 0], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 1): [0, 256, 0, 0], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 2): [0, 256, 0, 0], }) rb.pretend_min_part_hours_passed() rb.rebalance(seed=3) self.assertEqual(rb.dispersion, 0.0) self.assertEqual(rb._dispersion_graph, { (0,): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000'): [0, 0, 0, 256], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 0): [0, 128, 128, 0], (0, 0, '127.0.0.1:10000', 1): [0, 128, 128, 0], })

commit_message:
Fix cell(User Name) inline edit with a link in user table

We implement user table inline edit and user detail, so the User Name
cell will show input element as text while edting inline because the
cell data will be escaped while the cell has url, the patch fix it.

Closes-Bug: 1410832
Change-Id: Ic249259961624cc52f54c53a8cceb9f1a439e9bf

subject: Move self.rules implementations to TopDownTheory subclasses
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-23 18:51:14.000000000', 'files': ['congress/policy/topdown.py', 'congress/policy/nonrecursive.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/congress/commit/a3bcdcf6fee20d5766e72bc624f0d22e26dea9f7', 'message': "Move self.rules implementations to TopDownTheory subclasses

Previously, TopDownTheory assumed that it's subclasses would define a field
called self.rules.  This change eliminates that assumption by moving any code
that uses self.rules to the subclass NonrecursiveRuleTheory.

This new organization makes it cleaner for a subclass of TopDownTheory to
implement self.rules in a different way because now TopDownTheory will not be
reaching into self.rules at all.  Instead, methods like head_index(), head(),
and body() are all implemented in the subclass.

Change-Id: Id0c2ff09a11ca37dfafda6efda951d503d2b05b9
"}]
commit_message:
Move self.rules implementations to TopDownTheory subclasses

Previously, TopDownTheory assumed that it's subclasses would define a field
called self.rules.  This change eliminates that assumption by moving any code
that uses self.rules to the subclass NonrecursiveRuleTheory.

This new organization makes it cleaner for a subclass of TopDownTheory to
implement self.rules in a different way because now TopDownTheory will not be
reaching into self.rules at all.  Instead, methods like head_index(), head(),
and body() are all implemented in the subclass.

Change-Id: Id0c2ff09a11ca37dfafda6efda951d503d2b05b9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/18/149718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def head_index(self, table, match_literal=None): """Return head index. This routine must return all the formulas pertinent for top-down evaluation when a literal with TABLE is at the top of the stack. """ if table in self.rules: return self.rules.get_rules(table, match_literal) return [] def defined_tablenames(self): """Returns list of table names defined in/written to this theory.""" return self.rules.keys() def head(self, formula): """Given the output from head_index(), return the formula head. Given a FORMULA, return the thing to unify against. Usually, FORMULA is a compile.Rule, but it could be anything returned by HEAD_INDEX. """ return formula.head def body(self, formula): """Return formula body. Given a FORMULA, return a list of things to push onto the top-down eval stack. """ return formula.body

commit_message:
Use __slots__ for runtime classes

This change saves memory by using __slots__ instead of allocating a dict for
every instance of Location, Variable, Literal, Rule, and Event.  The overhead
of a dict is significant when there are many object instances using a dict to
store internal state.

Change-Id: I0f4f01e42f1641d624ab76ac304ad037767d0d9f

commit_message:
The first test for Vanilla 1.2.1 in Tempest style

The scenario of test for Vanilla 1.2.1  is

1. Create node group templates
2. Create cluster template
3. Create cluster
4. Wait for cluster to get "Active" status
5. Check cluster deployment
6. Delete resources

Change-Id: I5601413ead32f75bd83d9924b7c74c8634b28eb9

commit_message:
Create a new python-novaclient-core group

This group should inherit members from nova-core, but allows me to add
reviewers who are only core on python-novaclient. If you want a simple
population for the initial members, just add me and I will fix the rest
up.

Change-Id: I5b31a3b91da878d95d80154acb6dc4908fb9046d

commit_message:
Provide Rackspace service_name override

Rackspace puts two compute services in their catalog. This means that
keystone session code cannot find the right one without a name match
override.

Change-Id: I1bc06b97261341ad01bf84ebf5a12294cd0d383c

commit_message:
Refactor metering utility and view functions

Many of these functions have been copied to Tuskar-UI and then have
diverged in both places. This is an attempt to consolidate these
functions and eliminate any code duplication. These modifications
to horizon utility and view metering functions should make it possible
to delete the duplicated code from Tuskar-UI.

Change-Id: Ie73b350303a3e42229d87dbbfccf7ecff859cbd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/65/149665/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import loggingfrom horizon.utils import units import pytz LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) METER_API_MAPPINGS = { "instance": 'nova', "cpu": 'nova', "cpu_util": 'nova', "disk_read_requests": 'nova', "disk_write_requests": 'nova', "disk_read_bytes": 'nova', "disk_write_bytes": 'nova', "image": 'glance', "image_size": 'glance' } def calc_period(date_from, date_to, number_of_samples=400): delta_in_seconds = delta.days * 24 * 3600 + delta.seconds # TODO(lsmola) all timestamps should probably work with # current timezone. And also show the current timezone in chart. if date_options == "other": try: if date_from: date_from = pytz.utc.localize( datetime.datetime.strptime(date_from, "%Y-%m-%d")) else: # TODO(lsmola) there should be probably the date # of the first sample as default, so it correctly # counts the time window. Though I need ordering # and limit of samples to obtain that. pass if date_to: date_to = pytz.utc.localize( datetime.datetime.strptime(date_to, "%Y-%m-%d")) # It returns the beginning of the day, I want the end of # the day, so I add one day without a second. date_to = (date_to + datetime.timedelta(days=1) - datetime.timedelta(seconds=1)) else: date_to = timezone.now() except Exception: raise ValueError(_("The dates haven't been recognized")) date_from = date_to - datetime.timedelta(days=float(date_options))def get_resource_name(request, resource_id, resource_name, meter_name): resource = None try: if resource_name == "resource_id": meter_name = 'instance' if "instance" in meter_name else meter_name api_type = METER_API_MAPPINGS.get(meter_name, '') if api_type == 'nova': resource = api.nova.server_get(request, resource_id) elif api_type == 'glance': resource = api.glance.image_get(request, resource_id) except Exception: LOG.info(_("Failed to get the resource name: %s"), resource_id, exc_info=True) return resource.name if resource else resource_id def series_for_meter(request, aggregates, group_by, meter_id, meter_name, stats_name, unit, label=None): """Construct datapoint series for a meter from resource aggregates.""" series = [] for resource in aggregates: if resource.get_meter(meter_name): if label: name = label else: resource_name = ('id' if group_by == "project" else 'resource_id') resource_id = getattr(resource, resource_name) name = get_resource_name(request, resource_id, resource_name, meter_name) point = {'unit': unit, 'name': name, 'meter': meter_id, 'data': []} for statistic in resource.get_meter(meter_name): date = statistic.duration_end[:19] value = float(getattr(statistic, stats_name)) point['data'].append({'x': date, 'y': value}) series.append(point) return series def normalize_series_by_unit(series): """Transform series' values into a more human readable form: 1) Determine the data point with the maximum value 2) Decide the unit appropriate for this value (normalize it) 3) Convert other values to this new unit, if necessary """ if not series: return series source_unit = target_unit = series[0]['unit'] if not units.is_supported(source_unit): return series # Find the data point with the largest value and normalize it to # determine its unit - that will be the new unit maximum = max([d['y'] for point in series for d in point['data']]) unit = units.normalize(maximum, source_unit)[1] # If unit needs to be changed, set the new unit for all data points # and convert all values to that unit if units.is_larger(unit, target_unit): target_unit = unit for i, point in enumerate(series[:]): if point['unit'] != target_unit: series[i]['unit'] = target_unit for j, d in enumerate(point['data'][:]): series[i]['data'][j]['y'] = units.convert( d['y'], source_unit, target_unit, fmt=True)[0] return series
deleted_lines: def calc_period(date_from, date_to): # get the time delta in seconds if delta.days <= 0: # it's one day delta_in_seconds = 3600 * 24 else: delta_in_seconds = delta.days * 24 * 3600 + delta.seconds # Lets always show 400 samples in the chart. Know that it is # maximum amount of samples and it can be lower. number_of_samples = 400 if date_options == "other": if date_from and not isinstance(date_from, datetime.date): try: date_from = datetime.datetime.strptime(date_from, "%Y-%m-%d") except Exception: raise ValueError(_("From-date is not recognized")) if date_to: if not isinstance(date_to, datetime.date): try: date_to = datetime.datetime.strptime(date_to, "%Y-%m-%d") except Exception: raise ValueError(_("To-date is not recognized")) else: date_to = timezone.now() date_from = date_to - datetime.timedelta(days=int(date_options))

commit_message:
removing mandatory mark for post_creation tab

In launch instance form the post creation tab
having the * symbol, which means the the script
data is mandatory. but this is optional field.

so removing the the * symbol from the
post-creation tab.

(cherry picked from commit db33f9f944eed44171bbe744c88d8985275af26b)

Conflicts:
	openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/instances/workflows/create_instance.py

Closes-Bug: #1396501
Change-Id: If71cdd793723a2777356da773ae12deb68eb55e2

commit_message:
add missing icons for Project > Images filter

The fixed filter (Project | Shared with Me | Public) should have icons.
Using font awesome icons.

(cherry picked from commit d0254a859b6e9ee2443dddb15a3bebb6362498e3, minus
 the whitespace changes)

Conflicts:
	horizon/templates/horizon/common/_data_table_table_actions.html

Closes-Bug: #1367442
Change-Id: Ie9f228feebd31fc76adc62102a84235a93b23930

commit_message:
ephemeral file names should reflect fs type and mkfs command

At some point, we should switch over from ext3 to ext4. If we have
'default', we can't tell if a file was created with ext3 or ext4
as the file system. So we need a better way.

The name format is from discussion on the mailing list [1] and
was proposed by Pádraig Brady. Once we have this in place, we
can resurrect changeset to switch over from ext3 to ext4
first proposed by lifeless in
I833356af81df743a63d4442d389be82bc25f3914 and reverted in
I8de225729bbc77b263fcac2fa72b0e9cc6c1b2bf.

[1] http://markmail.org/message/xzwt2r7acyj7n33t

Related-Bug: #1266262
Change-Id: I795d4165d668018658967661f593a9eb48652b2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/50/142450/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_file_extension_for_os_type(os_type, specified_fs=None): mkfs_command = _MKFS_COMMAND.get(os_type, _DEFAULT_MKFS_COMMAND) if mkfs_command: extension = mkfs_command else: if not specified_fs: specified_fs = CONF.default_ephemeral_format if not specified_fs: specified_fs = _DEFAULT_FS_BY_OSTYPE.get(os_type, 'ext3') extension = specified_fs return utils.get_hash_str(extension)[:7]

commit_message:
Only enable one images filter button

Only one button for the images filter buttons should be enabled at any one time.
This is solved by removing the active class from all the filter buttons upon
selecting a filter.

(cherry picked from commit 8ea177b67a28b328b571b1140b7db01e303f6abc)

Closes-bug: 1365803
Change-Id: I9d7753684f144a6d66ccc5b09f830b360a07a620
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/18/149518/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // Remove active class from all buttons $(elm).find('div.table_filter button').each(function(index, btn) { $(btn).removeClass('active'); });

Change-Id: Icaa87ea803bc8d217eaece9bfa6a993af89fd460

commit_message:
Deprecate compute_node_get_by_service_id in DB API

As this method is only in use in the ComputeNode object, we can deprecate it
on the DB API layer and provide backwards compatibility within the object.

To be clear, we're now claiming that accessing the DB compute_nodes table
using a service_id field is no longer wanted and will be removed in
a next future once we are sure that all compute nodes are having an host field
set (ie. once all nodes in production are running Kilo code because we added
this field in a previous patch)

Partially-Implements blueprint detach-service-from-computenode

Change-Id: Icaa87ea803bc8d217eaece9bfa6a993af89fd460
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/128587/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adds a dynamic subheading to delimit floating IPs

When an instance has floating IP addresses associated to it, a new
subheading appears in the IP Address column in the instances table to
provide the user with a easy way to see which IPs are fixed and
which are floating.

Change-Id: I78ad832bf6e34516df6e1e2a31cca18af0bde8bc
Closes-Bug: 1284175
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/72/115372/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ip_groups = {} for ip_group, addresses in instance.addresses.iteritems(): ip_groups[ip_group] = {} ip_groups[ip_group]["floating"] = [] ip_groups[ip_group]["non_floating"] = [] for address in addresses: if ('OS-EXT-IPS:type' in address and address['OS-EXT-IPS:type'] == "floating"): ip_groups[ip_group]["floating"].append(address) else: ip_groups[ip_group]["non_floating"].append(address) context = { "ip_groups": ip_groups }

commit_message:
Add library oslo.concurrency in config-generator config file

We don't use oslo.concurrency config options in keystone now,
just in case it slips through unnoticed.

Change-Id: Ib5557765d3aa1e02c3a44e195e243c787f14dbf3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/70/137270/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: KEYSTONE_CONFIG_GENERATOR_EXTRA_LIBRARIES='keystone oslo.concurrency oslo.messaging oslo.db'

commit_message:
Fix incorrect session usage in tests

One of the helper function in tests have not used SQLAlchemy session
where it should have, resulting in 'database is locked' error in SQLite.

Fixed usage of sessions in this function.

Change-Id: I4ab3f99aad82ae29bacf27ea9331f246ebdfda69
Closes-bug: 1406315

commit_message:
fix test_ec2_list_credentials

The author used a wrong method to create ec2 credential and asserted
the wrong list data:
1. The method which creates a ec2 credential is self._get_ec2_cred()
2. cred_list should be r.result['credentials']

Change-Id: Ibb934ea404654adc99220096edf913a8aa8df7b3
Closes-Bug: #1413459
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/34/149134/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._get_ec2_cred() cred_list = r.result['credentials']

commit_message:
Add timeout for sending http requests

Change-Id: Ieda2e0a0cb2c072724d32d55337baf0eb61e7e8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/68/150168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sockethttp_timeout_opt = [ cfg.IntOpt('http_request_timeout', default=2, help='Timeout value in seconds for sending http requests') ] CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.register_opts(http_timeout_opt, group='api') CONF.import_opt('log_url_prefix', 'solum.worker.config', group='worker') http_req_timeout = CONF.api.http_request_timeout def get_http_connection(): return httplib2.Http(timeout=http_req_timeout) conn = get_http_connection() resp, _ = conn.request(status_url, 'POST', headers=headers, except (httplib2.HttpLib2Error, socket.error) as ex: LOG.warn("Error in sending status, status url: %s, repo token: %s," " error: %s" % (status_url, repo_token, ex)) conn = get_http_connection() resp, _ = conn.request(collab_url, headers=headers) except (httplib2.HttpLib2Error, socket.error) as ex: LOG.warn("Error in verifying collaborator, collab url: %s," " error: %s" % (collab_url, ex))
deleted_lines: cfg.CONF.import_opt('log_url_prefix', 'solum.worker.config', group='worker') http = httplib2.Http() resp, _ = http.request(status_url, 'POST', headers=headers, except httplib2.HttpLib2Error as ex: LOG.debug("Error in sending status %s" % ex) resp, _ = httplib2.Http().request(collab_url, headers=headers) except httplib2.HttpLib2Error as ex: LOG.info("Error in verifying collaborator %s" % ex)

commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fixes wrong hypervisor_version

The hypervisor_version will be stored in the database as
an Integer and it will be used by the scheduler, if required
by the image property 'hypervisor_version_requires'.

The hypervisor_version will then be converted back to a version
by spliting the int in groups of 3 digits.
E.g.: hypervisor_version 6003 is converted to '6.3'.

Currently, the reported hypervisor_version by the Hyper-V driver
is wrong. For example, for Windows Hyper-V / Server 2012 R2
or Windows 8.1, the hypervisor_version reported is '639600',
which will later be converted to 639.600 by the scheduler.

Closes-Bug: #1409258

Change-Id: Id991fefed08d1da2a68db4c27de72ac2252b1781
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/74/146274/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :returns: hypervisor version (ex. 6003) # NOTE(claudiub): The hypervisor_version will be stored in the database # as an Integer and it will be used by the scheduler, if required by # the image property 'hypervisor_version_requires'. # The hypervisor_version will then be converted back to a version # by spliting the int in groups of 3 digits. # E.g.: hypervisor_version 6003 is converted to '6.3'. version = self._hostutils.get_windows_version().split('.') version = int(version[0]) * 1000 + int(version[1])

subject: Create SolidFire Template account on init
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-27 01:49:37.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/drivers/solidfire.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/a36100bd34a22ddc3b620947809a41d328b1e949', 'message': 'Create SolidFire Template account on init

The standard flow in the SolidFire volume is to create
accounts dynamically as needed based on project id.
Unfortunately the clone_image method "forgot" about this
detail and calls the private clone_volume method without
a valid account resulting in an AccountNotFound
Exception.

The clone_image method is enabled using a specific account
provided via the configuration file.  Rather than worry
about dynamic account creation on clone_image call, this
patch just makes it part of the init phase.  We check to
see if template caching is enabled and if it is, just
go ahead and check/create the account on startup.

Closes-Bug: #1414760

Change-Id: I62f3f7aff958c097ae662d21b2c0f55a8d08f784
'}]
commit_message:
Create SolidFire Template account on init

The standard flow in the SolidFire volume is to create
accounts dynamically as needed based on project id.
Unfortunately the clone_image method "forgot" about this
detail and calls the private clone_volume method without
a valid account resulting in an AccountNotFound
Exception.

The clone_image method is enabled using a specific account
provided via the configuration file.  Rather than worry
about dynamic account creation on clone_image call, this
patch just makes it part of the init phase.  We check to
see if template caching is enabled and if it is, just
go ahead and check/create the account on startup.

Closes-Bug: #1414760

Change-Id: I62f3f7aff958c097ae662d21b2c0f55a8d08f784
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/02/150202/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.configuration.sf_allow_template_caching: account = self.configuration.sf_template_account_name self._create_sfaccount(account)

commit_message:
Change CDH plugin Processes Show_names

We change the Processes shownames of Cloudera plugin, so that users
will not be confused by the names without hint.

Closes-bug: #1411181
Change-Id: I666c69d9376e368bdd4c75abfdeadf853e0956d3

commit_message:
Change /POST to /ECP at federation config

Right now, is only possible to make k2k work via
SAML ECP, using it in the examples gives a hint
to the reader about the next steps (send SAML
assertion).

Change-Id: I5670328b55051f4c49c9a5557078079f6f19c804

subject: mirror/docker: fix the cleanup rule
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-27 15:44:06.000000000', 'files': ['mirror/docker/module.mk'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main/commit/01583bdca6449bac54a09d1e4a63dabf9ce4bec1', 'message': 'mirror/docker: fix the cleanup rule

After the commit 59b10c0d543af17eb88af43360df0f31337db68b ("Refactor Docker
cleanup") no docker containers/images get actually removed, so building ISO
exhausts the disk space quite quickly. To fix the problem
- Properly quote the special characters so awk command is valid
- Use xargs -r instead of reinventing it

Change-Id: Ie35906edde2fc04d5c3adef0578d1efb4e9a9d64
'}]
commit_message:
mirror/docker: fix the cleanup rule

After the commit 59b10c0d543af17eb88af43360df0f31337db68b ("Refactor Docker
cleanup") no docker containers/images get actually removed, so building ISO
exhausts the disk space quite quickly. To fix the problem
- Properly quote the special characters so awk command is valid
- Use xargs -r instead of reinventing it

Change-Id: Ie35906edde2fc04d5c3adef0578d1efb4e9a9d64
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-main refs/changes/62/150462/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: -sudo sh -c "docker ps -a | awk '/fuel/ { print \$$1; }' | xargs --no-run-if-empty docker rm -f" -sudo sh -c "docker images | awk '/fuel/ { print \$$3; }' | xargs --no-run-if-empty docker rmi -f"
deleted_lines: sudo sh -c 'docker ps && docker rm -f `docker ps -a | awk "/fuel/ {print $$1}"` 2>/dev/null || true' sudo sh -c 'docker images && docker rmi -f `docker images | awk "/fuel/ { print $$3; }"` 2>/dev/null || true'

commit_message:
mirror/ubuntu: handle several EXTRA_DEB_REPOS properly

At the moment a broken sources.list is produces if several EXTRA_DEB_REPOS
have been specified. Insert a missing whitespace between 'deb' and the URL.

Change-Id: I24446e8f6d3ab4300aaf197b19efcf5191d1e97e
Closes-Bug: #1415082

Since no timestamp was force in set_time_override(), now() was used by
default. The problem is that since we query on the last 10 minutes, if
now().minutes is <= 10, we might end up with the hourly aggregation
being returned so the assertEquals fail for a good reason.

Change-Id: Ia1b902440c5fc062ab2c944127e31a7dd7588d66
'}]
commit_message:
tests: fix relative test failing sometimes

Since no timestamp was force in set_time_override(), now() was used by
default. The problem is that since we query on the last 10 minutes, if
now().minutes is <= 10, we might end up with the hourly aggregation
being returned so the assertEquals fail for a good reason.

Change-Id: Ia1b902440c5fc062ab2c944127e31a7dd7588d66
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/06/150506/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-27 18:46:25.000000000', 'files': ['rally/benchmark/scenarios/vm/vmtasks.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/bf7fead727c14ae4d7c33a8b5347e636f7e724c1', 'message': 'Update the VMTask class with a boot_ping method

with a default of using floating_ip
allocation.  Alternatively depending on the
tenant network type, and if the rally host
has direct access to VLAN on which VMs are
being generated, private_network IP may
be suitable for ping testing.

Change-Id: I8f65a5527fad15bc5d264cb1b0cc382f1e51305f
'}]
commit_message:
Update the VMTask class with a boot_ping method

with a default of using floating_ip
allocation.  Alternatively depending on the
tenant network type, and if the rally host
has direct access to VLAN on which VMs are
being generated, private_network IP may
be suitable for ping testing.

Change-Id: I8f65a5527fad15bc5d264cb1b0cc382f1e51305f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/38/150538/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @types.set(image=types.ImageResourceType, flavor=types.FlavorResourceType) @validation.image_valid_on_flavor("flavor", "image") @validation.number("port", minval=1, maxval=65535, nullable=True, integer_only=True) @validation.external_network_exists("floating_network", "use_floatingip") @validation.required_services(consts.Service.NOVA, consts.Service.CINDER) @validation.required_openstack(users=True) @base.scenario(context={"cleanup": ["nova", "cinder"], "keypair": {}, "allow_ssh": {}}) def boot_ping(self, image, flavor, fixed_network="private", floating_network="public", ip_version=4, port=22, use_floatingip=True, **kwargs): """Boot server, run a script that outputs JSON, delete server. :param fixed_network: Network where instance is part of :param floating_network: External network used to get floating ip from :param ip_version: Version of ip protocol to use for connection :param port: Port to use for SSH connection :param use_floatingip: Whether to associate a floating ip for connection :returns: Dictionary containing two keys, data and errors. Data is JSON data output by the script. Errors is raw data from the script's standard error stream. """ fip = server = None net_wrap = network_wrapper.wrap(self.clients) internal_network = server.networks.keys()[0] fixed_ip = server.addresses[internal_network][0]["addr"] try: server = self._boot_server( self._generate_random_name("rally_novaserver_"), image, flavor, key_name='rally_ssh_key', **kwargs) self.check_network(server, fixed_network) if use_floatingip: fip = net_wrap.create_floating_ip(ext_network=floating_network, int_network=internal_network, tenant_id=server.tenant_id, fixed_ip=fixed_ip) self._associate_floating_ip(server, fip["ip"], fixed_address=fixed_ip) server_ip = fip["ip"] else: server_ip = fixed_ip self.wait_for_ping(server_ip) out = json.loads("{ \"ping\": 1 }") err = "" finally: if use_floatingip: self._dissociate_floating_ip(server, fip["ip"]) return {"data": out, "errors": err}

commit_message:
Update solum-app-setup

1. Added support for parameter

2. Added cmd option for app type

3. Make '--test-cmd' not required

4. Fix trigger uri temporarily

Change-Id: I9413faf70fff6be0ce6865824051f40db1a4734b

added_lines: from solumclient.common import yamlutils# TODO(james_li) Remove this once bug #1359516 is resolved TRIGGER_HOST = 'https://api.labs.rs-paas.com/'# TODO(james_li) Remove this once bug #1359516 is resolved url_pattern = re.compile(r'(v1/triggers.+)') filtered_url = ''.join([TRIGGER_HOST, match.group(0)])def create_plan(client, plan_file, param_file): if param_file: cmd = ['solum', 'app', 'create', plan_file, '--param-file', param_file] else: cmd = ['solum', 'app', 'create', plan_file] with open(plan_file) as definition_file: plan_definition = definition_file.read() definition = yamlutils.load(plan_definition) if param_file: with open(param_file) as param_f: param_definition = param_f.read() definition['parameters'] = yamlutils.load(param_definition) plan = client.plans.create(yamlutils.dump(definition)) plan_uri = create_plan(client, plan_file, args.param) parser.add_argument('--param-file', default=None, dest='param', help="parameter file")
deleted_lines: url_pattern = re.compile(r'^(http://)(.+)') filtered_url = ''.join(['https://', match.group(2)])def create_plan(client, plan_file): cmd = ['solum', 'app', 'create', plan_file] with open(plan_file) as definition_file: definition = definition_file.read() plan = client.plans.create(definition) plan_uri = create_plan(client, plan_file)

commit_message:
Visual Page for WebSSO

Co-Authored-By: Marek Denis <marek.denis@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: Steve Martinelli <stevemar@ca.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I10efb730de483bd18fd203cfe823e33029e79284
Implements bp websso-portal
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/29/133529/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================= Web Single Sign On Portal ========================= `bp example <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/webssoportal>`_ Provide a landing page inside of Keystone that can create a token an post it back to a requestor to support Federation, Kerberos, and X509 based authentication for visual Web sites that need to work with Keystone. Problem Description =================== With password based authentication, Horizon has been responsible for currying the shared secret between the user and Keystone. Cryptographically secure authentication mechanisms protect against this, as it leads to various Man-in-the-middle attack scenarios. If the Horizon server is compromised, it would grant the attacker access to the password for all users that log in. When coupled with a corporate directory, this poses an unacceptable risk. While Kerberos has a mechanism for constrained delegation that minimizes the risk, X509 and SAML do not. In addition, even S4U2Proxy provides a fairly broad degree of access to the Keystone user, as it must necessarily be capable of requesting any operation that the user can perform on the remote server. For SAML, there is no alternative than to do a visual redirect to the IdP in order to authenticate. If the IdP then redirects the user back to Horizon, the Keystone server must accept a SAML assertion without any of the guarantees that protect against replay attack; the SAML assertion is again a bearer token. The proper sequence is Horizon to Keystone to IdP to Keystone to Horizon. The Keystone server needs to enable the redirect to the IdP, and accept back the SAML assertion in order to create the token. The Keystone server can then generate sufficient code to POST the token back to Horizon. While it could also perform this stage via a redirect, it would have to have the token in the URL of the redirect, and that would be a security vulnerability. Proposed Change =============== Provide an HTML based WebSSO landing page in Keystone that performs the following: If the Keystone server is set with an unabiguous web login mechanism, properly perform the steps to request a token for the user. This means that if X509 Client certificates are an acceptable form of authentication, and the user has a proper X509, Keystone should create an unscoped token and post it back to Horiozn. The same is true for Kerberos. Autmoated processing for Federation is also possible if there is only a single IdP provisioned. If multiple Federation mechanisms are provisioned, the web portal has to be able to distinguish between those that should be publically listed and those that must be maintained private. The public list will be displayed as a list of documented hyperlinks. Each hyperlink will contain sufficient information to complete the token creation process once clicked. This means redirecting the user to the IdP, and providing a return link that will create the token and post to Horizon, as well as redirecting the user back to Horizon. For IdPs that are maintained privately, the user will be able to paste an URL into a text field that provides sufficient information to redirect the user to their own IdP. Keystone will validate the posted URL. If the URL is valid, it will perform the same steps as it would for the hyperlink of a public url, as well as set a cookie value with the IdP. On subsequent visites, Keystone should read the value from the Cookie to determine if it should display the private URL or not. Because Keystone will now have a visual component, it will need to be able to serve out two additional pages, one with CSS for theming, and one with Javascript for the post back to Keystone. These will not be generated from the dynamic content, but instead will be links added on to the response if the content type is HTML. THe Apache server needs to have a diffferent URL for each of the authN modules that it uses. For example, a single Keystone server that serves Kerberos and SAML will need to hand out different URLs for each. This need to dynamically list authentication mechanisms needs to be reflected in the paste file. Each authentication mechanism should have its own paste pipeline, but share a common set of filters with other mechanisms. Only extensions relevant to token creation (such as OS-FEDRATION) should be exposed in these pipelines. No other administrative functions should be exposed by these pipelines, either. Even the ability to validate a token is not required, and should be restricted if practical. Alternatives ------------ With Kerberos, S4U2Proxy can be used to provide constrained delegation, but it does not allow for any of the other login mechanisms. All of the user interface could be maintained in Horizon, but then sensitive information is provided beyond the scoped of the Keystone service. Horizon and any other web UI would need deep integration with the Keystone WebSSO process, and the two systems would effectivly be one tightly coupled system. Security Impact --------------- Describe any potential security impact on the system. Some of the items to consider include: * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? * Yes, Tokens. * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? * This is a new way to log in to Horizon. * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? * Not directly, but the WebSSO implementation may use either. * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? * No, it removes them from Horizon. * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. * Yes, at the WebSSO portal, the User must provide an URL. Additionally, Keystone will now have to be capable of rendering simple HTML. * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. * Probably no change to this risk, as all of the issues with exposing the Keystone server to the outside world still apply. Notifications Impact -------------------- No change to notifications. Other End User Impact --------------------- This will primarily be a visual feature. Users should not interact with it in an automated fashion. It should have no impact on Keystone client. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance impact should be minimal. Keystone will be serving out roughly the same amount of data as it is in during a Horizon login today, with the addition of some static files. With proper page lifespace tuning for these pages, the impact should be nominal. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- * The token creation process today assumes a single `method` for tokens. Each of the exposed authentication mechanisms should instead allow for a separate configured method. To reduce duplication, this configuration will be performed in the paste file as a filter on the auth pipeline. The Javascript and CSS files for HTML rendering will be specified as static resources. These should each be a list of files that are included in the order specified. While this can be done either in the paste file or the keystone configuration file, it makes more sense to use the paste file, as they are generic web technoligies. * This feature will be enabled based on changes to both the paste files and the Apache HTTPD configuration file. It should not require any additional editing by end deployers afterwards. * These changes should not break current continuous deployment. In order to test these mechanisms, CI will need a series of Federation protocol implementations, to include X509 Client certificate support, Kerberos, SAML, and additional protoclas as supported. The focus should be on testing the Integration with Horizon. Developer Impact ---------------- The biggest impact should be a restructuring of the paste file to reduce duplication and to better support the specific URLs for each authentication mechanism. This will change where in the file filters are configured if those filters are common actrosss multiple pipelines. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Who is leading the writing of the code? Or is this a blueprint where you're throwing it out there to see who picks it up? If more than one person is working on the implementation, please designate the primary author and contact. Primary assignee: ayoung Adam Young ayoung@redhat.com Other contributors: Marek Denis Jose Castro Leon Work Items ---------- * Refactor paste file to reduce duplication of common filters. * Splite the v3 service APIs into separate pipelines. * Remove POST /v3/auth/tokens from the remainder of the auth pipeline * split configuration of the auth plugin off the token provider and make into a filter * Replace the json filter with a content-type filter than can render either html or JSON based on the accepts header. This will be used for the portions of Keytone exposed for visual web use only. * Create a simple renderer for HTML content * Extend the IDP entity to indicate whether a given IDP is public or private * Create a JSON home entity to describe what the landing page for the IDP list should look like. It needs to contain sufficient information to allow for the creation of an HTML form for the case where there are private IdPs. * Enable HTML content renderer to create a form based on JSON home data. Dependencies ============ * This blueprint depends only on existing OS-FEDERATION based work. * Once this is implemented, Django-openstack-auth will need a configuration option to be able to triggere the redirect and to handle the posting of the token back from Keystone. * This feature should not require any external dependencies. Documentation Impact ==================== Configuration manual will have to explain how to set up the Apache server to expose the various authentication mechanisms. References ========== CERN Patch to Keystone support WebSSO https://github.com/cernops/keystone/commit/66dabd94b4ad32abca171cef9192210fec289235 CERN Patch to Django-Openstack-Auth to support WebSSO https://github.com/cernops/django_openstack_auth/commit/b7e5b28a83a88b259bfaddbd754c70e1bb420447

commit_message:
Add driver internal info field to nodes table

Driver should have its own infos, which are not input from admin like
driver_info and they may vary during the deployment process.
They can only be used by driver itself.

Implements blueprint driver-internal-info
Change-Id: I4fc647708d899047f5a802b1d7301d403c9f580f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/44/148944/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================== Driver Internal Info ================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/ironic/+spec/driver-internal-info Problem description =================== Driver should have its own infos which are invisible to user/admin. These infos are not input from admin like driver_info and they may vary during the deployment process. They can only be used by driver itself. One example is ipmitool. Not all IPMI firmware support set boot device persistent, so we need to save this info locally. Proposed change =============== Add a new table driver_internal_info to save driver own infos, which will not expose to Admin/user via API. Add ensure_next_boot_device into base.ManagementInterface. During PXE deploy processing, the target machine will boot by itself. Some Drivers has to set next boot device again in _continue_deploy(). Add ensure_next_boot_device into base.ManagementInterface to support this unconditionally. Alternatives ------------ Keep saving above infos in driver_info. But user may confuse about the change. Data model impact ----------------- Add a new table driver_internal_info. As one node has only one driver, so driver_internal_info will map to node as many to one. It only contains id, node_id and key/value pair. REST API impact --------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- Add ensure_next_boot_device into base.ManagementInterface. Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Other drivers should save their own infos into the new table. Other drivers dont have to care about the ensure_next_boot_device only if they have the same issue of ipmitool driver. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tan-lin-good@gmail.com Work Items ---------- Add table driver_internal_info. Add correspond db api. Add a new object DriverInternalinfo. Support clean a node's driver_internal_infos when it changes its driver. Update some drivers with this feature. Add ensure_next_boot_device() to base.ManagementInterface. Update PXE deploy process with this feature. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Add unit tests. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== None Documentation Impact ==================== Update the developer documentation. References ========== None

commit_message:
Added tests for PATCH requests
Related-Bug: #1367473

Change-Id: Iac03c3381bb0de4e7e2444fa3f9aa4150bde6fa7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/47/121747/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_components_patch(self): self.skipTest("PATCH not implemented (returns 404): #1367473") uuid, assembly_uuid, plan_uuid = self._create_component() updated_data = {'name': 'test_service_updated', 'description': 'desc updated', 'plan_uri': "%s/v1/plans/%s" % (self.client.base_url, plan_uuid), 'assembly_uuid': assembly_uuid} updated_json = json.dumps(updated_data) resp, body = self.client.patch('v1/components/%s' % uuid, updated_json) self.assertEqual(resp.status, 200) json_data = json.loads(body) self._assert_output_expected(json_data, updated_data) self._delete_component(uuid, assembly_uuid, plan_uuid) def test_components_patch_not_found(self): updated_data = {'name': 'test_service_updated', 'description': 'desc updated', 'plan_uri': "%s/v1/plans/%s" % (self.client.base_url, 'not_found'), 'assembly_uuid': 'not_found'} updated_json = json.dumps(updated_data) self.assertRaises(tempest_exceptions.NotFound, self.client.patch, 'v1/components/not_found', updated_json) def test_components_patch_none(self): self.skipTest("PATCH not implemented (returns 404): #1367473") self.assertRaises(tempest_exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.patch, 'v1/components/any', "{}")

for consistency.

added_lines: from openstackclient.network import common network_client = self.app.client_manager.network nic_info = {"net-id": "", "v4-fixed-ip": "", "v6-fixed-ip": "", "port-id": ""} if nic_info["net-id"] != '': nic_info["net-id"] = common.find(network_client, 'network', 'networks', nic_info["net-id"]) if nic_info["port-id"] != '': nic_info["port-id"] = common.find(network_client, 'port', 'ports', nic_info["port-id"])

commit_message:
Partially revert database tests patches.

This partially reverts commit 01fb4f0af450a07619c26a72011c9a564b8b0bd7
and 5b9b43b88015348ef6816eba73283f7e5a1cc2fb

The first commit slowed down the test by a factor of 4, which turns out
be too much to my taste.
The second one is buggy as it tries to use a directory for locking that
is unique to a process, but since we run tests in parrallel, we need a
unique directory for ALL the process, so it has to be passed down as a
env variable.

Change-Id: I3fcccef0915eace1b23297d38d1a0a4212a13ff3

subject: Switch to oslo.vmware API for reading and writing files

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-16 14:37:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5a182e9a67baa1232c0e4b0f15f95babace18a1b', 'message': 'Switch to oslo.vmware API for reading and writing files

This started off as an exercise to remove httplib.HTTPSConnection
to prevent MiM attacks but morphed into a full fledged replacement
of code in read_write_util to use functionality from oslo.vmware.

As a side-effect, we remove the use of the HTTPSConnection and
are switching over to requests library as well.

commit_message:
Switch to oslo.vmware API for reading and writing files

This started off as an exercise to remove httplib.HTTPSConnection
to prevent MiM attacks but morphed into a full fledged replacement
of code in read_write_util to use functionality from oslo.vmware.

As a side-effect, we remove the use of the HTTPSConnection and
are switching over to requests library as well.

Closes-Bug: #1374000
Change-Id: I917c34042c501af03725b0504542e00e7d80e511
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/18/142118/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: write_file_handle = rw_handles.FileWriteHandle( read_file_handle = rw_handles.ImageReadHandle(read_iter) write_file_handle = rw_handles.FileWriteHandle( host, 443, dc_name, ds_name, cookies, file_path, file_size)
deleted_lines: write_file_handle = read_write_util.VMwareHTTPWriteFile( read_file_handle = read_write_util.GlanceFileRead(read_iter) write_file_handle = read_write_util.VMwareHTTPWriteFile( host, dc_name, ds_name, cookies, file_path, file_size)

commit_message:
Cleanup bad JSON files

- Add missing commas
- Replace single quote with double quote
- events field contains a list of events (event-create-req.json)
- Remove empty files
- Adds a JSON validation test to the docs pipeline

Co-Authored-By: Nicolas Simonds <nic@metacloud.com>
Change-Id: I9a4a9b6b8e2da73b5f25145be3b2faa44ebdb340

commit_message:
ML2 Mechanism Driver for SeaMicro chassis

The purpose of this blueprint is to add support for SeaMicro chassis
in OpenStack neutron as a ML2 mechanism driver.

Change-Id: Ic7de745ab862a5259760f555ddc2ca044eacd753
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/74/144274/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= ML2 Mechanism Driver for SeaMicro chassis ========================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/seamicro-mechanism-driver The purpose of this blueprint is to add support for SeaMicro chassis in OpenStack neutron as a ML2 mechanism driver. Problem Description =================== This blueprint proposes support for SeaMicro chassis in OpenStack neutron as a ML2 mechanism driver. This mechansim driver will interact with the SeaMicro chassis via REST APIs to dynamically configure and manage networking for instances created via OpenStack. Proposed Change =============== The diagram below provides a high level overview of the interactions between SeaMicro chassis and OpenStack components. Flows:: +------------------------------+ | Neutron Server | | with ML2 Plugin | | | | +----------------+ | | SeaMicro | | | Mechanism | +--------------------+ +-------| | Driver | | | | | +-+--+-------------+ REST API | | | +---+ | SeaMicro Client +-----------------+ | | | +-----------+------------------+ | SeaMicro Chasiss | | | | | | | | | | | +--------------------------+ | | | | | L2 Agent | OpenVSwitch +---------------------+ | | | +--------------------------+ +-+------------------+ | | | | | | +---+ Compute 1 | | | | | | | +--------------------------+ | | | | | | +--------------------------+ | | | L2 Agent | OpenVSwitch +-----------------------+ | +--------------------------+ | | | +-------+ Compute 2 | | | +--------------------------+ The SeaMicro mechanism driver will handle all the postcommit events for network, subnets and ports. We are going to create VLAN on SeaMicro chassis when the network is created and assign respective VALN ID to servers. Data Model Impact ----------------- This mechanism driver introduces two new tables which are specific to the SeaMicro mechanism driver. * SeaMicroNetwork: Stores network UUID ,network type, vlan , tenant ID. * SeaMicroPorts: Stores port UUID and its binding with network UUID. A database migration is included to create the tables for these models. No existing models are changed. REST API Impact --------------- None. Security Impact --------------- None. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ The performance of SeaMicro ML2 mechanism driver will depend on the responsiveness of the SeaMicro Client. IPv6 Impact ----------- None. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- The deployer must provide the following in order to be able to connect to a SeaMicro chassis. * IP address of SeaMicro chassis. * Admin credentials (username and password) to log into SeaMicro chassis. * Add "seamicro" as a ML2 driver. * Add Compute host binding with its Server ID. These should be provided in: /opt/stack/neutron/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf_seamicro.ini Example: [ml2_mech_seamicro:<IP address of SeaMicro chassis>] # username=<credential username> # password=<credential password> # Compute1=<Server ID> # Compute2=<Server ID> Developer Impact ---------------- None. Community Impact ---------------- This change adds a new mechanism driver for ML2 plugin aligning with the community direction. Alternatives ------------ None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <harshada.kakad> Work Items ---------- Work Items can be roughly divided into the following tasks: * Mechanism driver to handle network/subnet/port CRUD requests. * Unit test cases to test the mechanism driver. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit Testing will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ Configuration details for this mechanism driver. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None. References ========== None.

subject: Ignore warnings from contextlib.nested
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-22 20:38:55.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/fixtures.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/77b47f61fe13e3301a8873aea4321fae49937710', 'message': 'Ignore warnings from contextlib.nested

We have a lot of warnings in py27 jobs about the
with statements that use contextlib.nested()
construct. We should just ignore them for now.

Alternatives tried included
- multiple manager form of the with statement which essentially
needed to be line wrapped with \ and would have caused a lot of
code changes.
- custom implementation of nested() turned out to be
more complicated than initially thought.

Change-Id: I1b8ed531be91faeb0067aad7338bd8868d16e50d
'}]
commit_message:
Ignore warnings from contextlib.nested

We have a lot of warnings in py27 jobs about the
with statements that use contextlib.nested()
construct. We should just ignore them for now.

Alternatives tried included
- multiple manager form of the with statement which essentially
needed to be line wrapped with \ and would have caused a lot of
code changes.
- custom implementation of nested() turned out to be
more complicated than initially thought.

Change-Id: I1b8ed531be91faeb0067aad7338bd8868d16e50d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/94/149394/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: warnings.filterwarnings('ignore', message='With-statements now directly support' ' multiple context managers')

subject: dhcp: move dnsmasq version check to sanity_check
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-20 14:37:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/97a2963d6d96e4f114bb0edcefa78ab60865b845', 'message': "dhcp: move dnsmasq version check to sanity_check

We should avoid checking version numbers in runtime. In that way, we may
break some existing setups by minimal version bumps that are often not
critical for operation. One example is a recent version bump to support
IPv6 DHCP stateful address assignment mode. Even though old dnsmasq
version made this particular mode to fail to assign addresses to
instances, other IPv6 modes, and, even more importantly, all IPv4
networks continued to operate with no issues.

So let's move the fatal check from DHCP agent into sanity_check tool to
avoid potential breakages on neutron update.

In ideal world, we would make the check smarter. Since current version
cap is due to missing hwaddr matching for IPv6 clients for old dnsmasq
versions, we could preconfigure and start up dnsmasq server in a
namespace, and request a IPv6 lease from it. That would require a DHCP
IPv6 client installed though, and I'm not sure we can always expect it
to be present, so leaving it as-is for now.

Since DHCP drivers are pluggable, we cannot drop check_version method
from DhcpBase to support other drivers that may live in the wild.

Note: we could mark the method as deprecated if we really want to get
rid of it.

Closes-Bug: #1412818
Change-Id: I7a75cccf3880d3b18005ae0def5a17dfd8a00182

commit_message:
dhcp: move dnsmasq version check to sanity_check

We should avoid checking version numbers in runtime. In that way, we may
break some existing setups by minimal version bumps that are often not
critical for operation. One example is a recent version bump to support
IPv6 DHCP stateful address assignment mode. Even though old dnsmasq
version made this particular mode to fail to assign addresses to
instances, other IPv6 modes, and, even more importantly, all IPv4
networks continued to operate with no issues.

So let's move the fatal check from DHCP agent into sanity_check tool to
avoid potential breakages on neutron update.

In ideal world, we would make the check smarter. Since current version
cap is due to missing hwaddr matching for IPv6 clients for old dnsmasq
versions, we could preconfigure and start up dnsmasq server in a
namespace, and request a IPv6 lease from it. That would require a DHCP
IPv6 client installed though, and I'm not sure we can always expect it
to be present, so leaving it as-is for now.

Since DHCP drivers are pluggable, we cannot drop check_version method
from DhcpBase to support other drivers that may live in the wild.

Note: we could mark the method as deprecated if we really want to get
rid of it.

Closes-Bug: #1412818
Change-Id: I7a75cccf3880d3b18005ae0def5a17dfd8a00182
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/77/148577/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: with mock.patch.object(dhcp.Dnsmasq, 'check_version') as check_v: check_v.return_value = dhcp.Dnsmasq.MINIMUM_VERSION self.dhcp = dhcp_agent.DhcpAgent(HOSTNAME)

commit_message:
Add unit test for quota remains functionality

get_project_quotas support a "remain" parameter to add the remaining
space into the returned data structure. This will be tested by the
introduced test.

Change-Id: I612d58365d2b584b0a93ffd65d91cd26839420f6
Partial-Bug: #1348635

commit_message:
zmq: Refactor test case shared code

A number of the ZMQ test cases shared the same setUp method; refactor
and introduce a base test case class to share this code across all
appropriate ZMQ test cases.

Change-Id: I59300464af001c343efcd4f3f33d34c972da2b87
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/54/144954/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class ZmqBaseTestCase(test_utils.BaseTestCase): """Base test case for all ZMQ tests that make use of the ZMQ Proxy""" @testtools.skipIf(impl_zmq is None, "zmq not available") def setUp(self): super(ZmqBaseTestCase, self).setUp() self.messaging_conf.transport_driver = 'zmq' # Get driver transport = messaging.get_transport(self.conf) self.driver = transport._driver # Set config values self.internal_ipc_dir = self.useFixture(fixtures.TempDir()).path kwargs = {'rpc_zmq_bind_address': '127.0.0.1', 'rpc_zmq_host': '127.0.0.1', 'rpc_response_timeout': 5, 'rpc_zmq_port': get_unused_port(), 'rpc_zmq_ipc_dir': self.internal_ipc_dir} self.config(**kwargs) # Start RPC LOG.info("Running internal zmq receiver.") self.reactor = impl_zmq.ZmqProxy(self.conf) self.reactor.consume_in_thread() self.matchmaker = impl_zmq._get_matchmaker(host='127.0.0.1') self.addCleanup(stopRpc(self.__dict__)) class TestZmqBasics(ZmqBaseTestCase):class TestZmqConnection(ZmqBaseTestCase):class TestZmqListener(ZmqBaseTestCase):class TestZmqDriver(ZmqBaseTestCase):

commit_message:
utils: Allow discovery of private key in ~/.ssh

A SSHPool class object, used to hold ssh connections, fails to
authenticate to the server in its create () method if the path to
SSH private key or user password is not passed during object creation.
The create () method does not allow private key to be discovered in
the default ~/.ssh folder when trying to authenticate or connect
to the SSH server. Instead allow auto discovery of the key in the
paramiko SSHClient's connect method (called in create () method) if the
path to private key or password is not provided.

Also make the following minor cleanups in the

create() method of SSHPool class:
- pass the path to the key file input directly to the SSHClient's
  connect () method using the appropriate parameter, keyfile, instead
  of picking key from key file and passing that as 'pkey' parameter.
- restrict the try except block to only the steps involved in
  connecting to the SSH server.
- reraise the exception that would be raised by the Paramiko library
  instead of raising own exception.

initialization method of SSHPool class:
- rename the attribute privatekey as path_to_private_key to accurately
  reflect what it refers to, the path of the private key file.

Change-Id: I590702d97086d33245894fd686250e75e8e359f2
Closes-Bug: #1412782
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/34/148534/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Error connecting via ssh: %s") % e raise
deleted_lines: self.privatekey = privatekey try: ssh = paramiko.SSHClient() ssh.set_missing_host_key_policy(paramiko.AutoAddPolicy()) if self.privatekey: pkfile = os.path.expanduser(self.privatekey) self.privatekey = paramiko.RSAKey.from_private_key_file(pkfile) elif not self.password: msg = _("Specify a password or private_key") raise exception.ManilaException(msg) pkey=self.privatekey, msg = _("Error connecting via ssh: %s") % e raise paramiko.SSHException(msg)

commit_message:
Fixes Error message during image upload due to file filtering

When filtering supported file types in Glance, uploading a none supported
file gives a none informative/misleading error on Horizon -> Error:
Unable to create new image.
Uploading same image in Glance CLI returns a better warning: Invalid
disk format.

Change-Id: I3dced3a1056bd5bb4495881f246fcab39fbc1bff
Closes-bug: #1296722

commit_message:
Fix disappearing Sahara workflow navbar in 'Jobs' panel

The jquery selector used before in Sahara-specific js was too wide so
it could seize even the modal workflows from the depth of modal stack
(i.e. currently hidden workflows) - which lead to damaging these
workflows' DOM - the fact which became evident during unwinding the
modal stack. The patch contains the fix for the 'Jobs' panel as well
as for other copy-pasted snippets of workflow-handling code.

Change-Id: Id2544c18c27ae3432e6fa43f19cd1459ffb34871
Closes-Bug: #1414586
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/60/150060/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Replace lockfile by oslo_concurrency

This drops lockfile in favor of oslo_concurrency in order to unify
Horizon with the rest of the OpenStack projects.

Change-Id: I245fa3ca3926c279cb760f1d4530c511b140a8ea
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/39/148539/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_concurrency import lockutils lock = lockutils.external_lock(key_file)

commit_message:
Bump alembic to 0.7.2

Alembic 0.7.2 fixes a significant bug in 0.7.1 with handling
deduplication of unique indexes and unique constraints.

https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/alembic/issue/251/

This bug fix is necessary for Nova to start utilizing existing
functionality in oslo.db that compares the results of the migrations
with the model.

Change-Id: I63fb3ad22746ed8c9c2197d8216e4642396c8019
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/62/150162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: alembic>=0.7.2

commit_message:
Switch to using oslo_* instead of oslo.*

The oslo team is recommending everyone to switch to the
non-namespaced versions of libraries. Updating the hacking
rule to include a check to prevent oslo.* import from
creeping back in.
oslo.messaging is the only exception because this package doesn't
currently support non-namespaced imports.

Change-Id: I3987e651bc880c8ffa7c0105df0298679dcd3a43

commit_message:
Cleanup service templates

* Add attributes needed in most cases
* Cleanup clutter and old comments
* Cleanup unused old attributes

Change-Id: I19c3a0ed4f37371d0aa1886f1a7fd865e404c841

commit_message:
Use PEP440 normalized versions

Switch to using X.Y.Z format (think: 2015.1.0) versions for final
versions, X.Y.Z{b,rc}N for milestones and release candidates, to
match PEP440-normalized versions that setuptools and our tooling
now produce for our tarballs.

Change-Id: I42bd41b7fd2d9f1e9ead8a76f11a54926b637fdf

commit_message:
Updated forgotten ansible-lxc-rpc file in icehouse

The ansible-lxc-rpc file was a hold-over file that was forgotten when
we migrated to icehouse. This file needed to be renamed and pointed at
the correct branch.

Change-Id: I5ec2bc1ba752bc788d86da738963289dea8671db

commit_message:
Split packages into nova and deps, and allow not installing them.

This work attempts to split the attributes for packages into two
seperate buckets, one for dependencies and one for openstack packages.

This is part of a larger project to allow the installation of nova
directly from git, rather than from packages.

Change-Id: Ifef646d21afd12823bae2830b1059599ae1e5ff9

commit_message:
Support qemu as virt_type

KVM currently is the default hypervisor to apply all compute nodes,
however kvm cannot work on virtual machine. So the fix will automatically
switch to qemu from kvm when it runs on top of a vm and
openstack.compute.libvirt.virt_auto is true.

Change-Id: I7ff87f7d9e77c1434eb2f39e4c43f208aa90d43a
Closes-Bug: #1334913
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cookbook-openstack-compute refs/changes/02/103702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # qemu: '0' hardware support kvm; '1' server doesn't support kvm, qemu needed qemu = `egrep '(vmx|svm)' /proc/cpuinfo >/dev/null;echo $?`.delete("\n") if qemu.eql?("1") node.override["openstack"]["compute"]["libvirt"]["virt_type"] = "qemu" end

commit_message:
Allow overriding name for periodic tasks

After introducing external tasks via add_periodic_task, task name
is no longer necessary unique. This patch allows overriding
name in @periodic_task.

Change-Id: I7587aea9bd61360a01d570c925c0c980562b9d8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/54/148854/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @periodic_task(spacing=N [, run_immediately=[True|False]] [, name=[None|"string"]) starts. If name is not provided, __name__ of function is used. f._periodic_name = kwargs.pop('name', f.__name__) name = task._periodic_name self._periodic_last_run[task._periodic_name] = ( task._periodic_last_run)
deleted_lines: @periodic_task(spacing=N [, run_immediately=[True|False]]) starts. name = task.__name__ self._periodic_last_run[task.__name__] = task._periodic_last_run

commit_message:
dhcp_domain should be set to empty in nova.conf when we use neutron for network.

If we don't set dhcp_domain full fqdn look like this :
vm01.example.net.novalocal

Change-Id: Ib713aed57cdc053011c5dac1fe922df20ed1b1c8
Closes-Bug: 1338664

commit_message:
Separate add_periodic_task from the metaclass __init__

It can be handy to add periodic tasks that are not within the class
(our use case is for Ironic drivers).

Change-Id: I405b8a113b3f4adda0548b6a7332d01bbece9e9a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/67/147567/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def add_periodic_task(cls, task): """Add a periodic task to the list of periodic tasks. The task should already be decorated by @periodic_task. """ name = task.__name__ if task._periodic_spacing < 0: LOG.info(_LI('Skipping periodic task %(task)s because ' 'its interval is negative'), {'task': name}) return if not task._periodic_enabled: LOG.info(_LI('Skipping periodic task %(task)s because ' 'it is disabled'), {'task': name}) return # A periodic spacing of zero indicates that this task should # be run on the default interval to avoid running too # frequently. if task._periodic_spacing == 0: task._periodic_spacing = DEFAULT_INTERVAL cls._periodic_tasks.append((name, task)) cls._periodic_spacing[name] = task._periodic_spacing cls.add_periodic_task(value)
deleted_lines: task = value name = task.__name__ if task._periodic_spacing < 0: LOG.info(_LI('Skipping periodic task %(task)s because ' 'its interval is negative'), {'task': name}) continue if not task._periodic_enabled: LOG.info(_LI('Skipping periodic task %(task)s because ' 'it is disabled'), {'task': name}) continue # A periodic spacing of zero indicates that this task should # be run on the default interval to avoid running too # frequently. if task._periodic_spacing == 0: task._periodic_spacing = DEFAULT_INTERVAL cls._periodic_tasks.append((name, task)) cls._periodic_spacing[name] = task._periodic_spacing

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-26 22:23:51.000000000', 'files': ['oslosphinx/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslosphinx/commit/7c282dc14a0c7a718a2f477e958822e4cf186d2a', 'message': 'Allow alternate OpenStack themes

commit_message:
Allow alternate OpenStack themes

By default oslosphinx forces projects that use it to use the theme
contained in the package. The documentation team wants to provide a
separate theme for some parts of the docs.openstack.org site. They are
going to distribute it in their own package, but do still want to be
able to use other features of oslosphinx. This change allows any name
that starts "openstack" to be used, while retaining the default behavior
of inserting the "openstack" theme if a project is using a different
default or has not set a theme.

Change-Id: I7a2c5a5c3805685b8fa0baaa47393d5fec312f30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslosphinx refs/changes/65/150165/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # force the theme setting to use the one in the package unless # another openstack theme is already selected. This is done here, # instead of in setup(), because conf.py is read after setup() # runs, so if the conf contains these values the user values # overwrite these. That's not bad for the theme, but it breaks the # search path. if not app.config.html_theme.startswith('openstack'): app.config.html_theme = 'openstack'
deleted_lines: # force the theme setting to use the one in the package. This is # done here, instead of in setup(), because conf.py is read after # setup() runs, so if the conf contains these values the user # values overwrite these. That's not bad for the theme, but it # breaks the search path. app.config.html_theme = 'openstack'
